text: But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name:
text_kjv: But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name:
text_niv: Yet to all who received him, to those who believed in his name, he gave the right to become children of God—
text_esv: But to all who did receive him, who believed in his name, he gave the right to become children of God,
text_nlt: But to all who believed him and accepted him, he gave the right to become children of God.
text_msg: But whoever did want him, who believed he was who he claimed and would do what he said, He made to be their true selves, their child-of-God selves.
text_nasb: But as many as received Him, to them He gave the right to become children of God, [even] to those who believe in His name,
context: John 1:12 appears in the prologue of John's Gospel, written around 85-95 AD to a diverse audience including Jews and Gentiles. This verse follows the tragic statement that Jesus 'came to that which was his own, but his own did not receive him' (v.11), referring to Israel's general rejection of their Messiah. The prologue (John 1:1-18) establishes Jesus as the eternal Word who became flesh, the light of the world, and the revelation of God's glory. John wrote to demonstrate that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God, so that readers might believe and have life in His name (20:31). The historical context includes the temple's destruction (70 AD) and growing tensions between Jewish Christians and synagogue Judaism. This verse provides hope amid rejection, showing that God's family extends beyond ethnic boundaries to include all who believe, regardless of their background or previous relationship with God.
meaning: This verse reveals the fundamental gospel truth about spiritual adoption and regeneration. The word 'received' (Greek: lambano) means to actively welcome or accept, while 'believed' (Greek: pisteuo) indicates ongoing trust and faith. These aren't separate actions but two aspects of the same response to Christ. 'In his name' represents Jesus' complete person, character, and authority—not merely intellectual acknowledgment but personal surrender to who He is. The 'right' or 'authority' (Greek: exousia) to become God's children is a legal privilege granted by divine grace, not earned through human effort. 'Children of God' (Greek: tekna theou) emphasizes our new nature and family relationship, distinct from mere servants or subjects. This adoption transcends natural birth, ethnicity, or religious heritage—it's entirely dependent on God's gracious initiative. The verse highlights the contrast between human rejection (v.11) and divine acceptance, showing that while many refused Christ, God provides an open invitation to all who respond in faith. This transformation from outsider to family member represents the core of Christian salvation—a complete change in identity, status, and relationship with God through Christ alone.
application: This verse transforms how believers understand their identity and security. As God's children, we possess unshakeable worth that doesn't depend on performance, achievements, or others' opinions. When facing rejection, failure, or self-doubt, remember that your primary identity is 'child of God'—a status no one can revoke. This truth should eliminate both pride and despair, recognizing that our position comes through grace alone. In relationships, extend the same unconditional acceptance God shows us. Look beyond surface differences to see potential brothers and sisters in Christ. This verse also calls us to examine our own response to Jesus—have we truly 'received' Him, or merely acknowledged Him intellectually? Genuine faith involves ongoing trust and surrender, not just a one-time decision. For parents, this reminds us that our children's ultimate security comes from their relationship with their heavenly Father, not our parenting perfection. In ministry, remember that God's family includes people from every background—our role is to welcome others as Christ welcomed us. When sharing the gospel, emphasize this incredible invitation: God wants to adopt people into His family. This isn't about joining a religion but entering a relationship that changes everything about how we see ourselves and others.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank You for the incredible privilege of being called Your child. When Your own people rejected Jesus, You opened Your arms to receive all who would believe. Help me never take this amazing grace for granted. Strengthen my faith to truly receive Christ daily, not just in word but in complete surrender to His lordship. When I feel rejected or worthless, remind me of my true identity as Your beloved child. Give me eyes to see others as potential family members, extending the same welcome You've shown me. Help me live worthy of this calling, reflecting Your character as Your child. Transform my heart to receive Your love fully and share it generously. Thank You that this relationship is secure, based on Your faithfulness, not my performance. May my life demonstrate the joy and confidence that comes from knowing I belong to You. In Jesus' precious name, Amen.

faqs.answer: These represent two aspects of the same spiritual response, not separate requirements. 'Receiving' emphasizes the active welcome and acceptance of Jesus as He is, while 'believing in His name' focuses on ongoing trust in His complete person and authority. Together, they describe genuine faith that involves both an initial decision and continued reliance on Christ for salvation and daily life.
faqs.question: What's the difference between receiving Christ and believing in His name?

faqs.answer: Faith is absolutely required. This verse clearly states that only 'those who received him' and 'believed in his name' receive the right to become God's children. While God loves everyone and desires all to be saved, spiritual adoption requires a personal response of faith. It's an invitation extended to all, but only activated through individual belief and acceptance of Christ.
faqs.question: Does everyone automatically become God's child, or is faith required?

faqs.answer: The word 'right' (Greek: exousia) means authority or privilege. It's a legal term indicating that God grants believers the legitimate standing to be called His children. This isn't earned through good works or heritage, but given as a gift through faith. It represents our new legal and relational status—we're not just forgiven criminals, but adopted family members with full privileges.
faqs.question: What does it mean to have the 'right' to become God's children?

faqs.answer: As God's child, you have direct access to Him in prayer, security in His love regardless of circumstances, and the Holy Spirit's guidance. This identity should eliminate fear-based living and people-pleasing, replacing them with confidence in God's acceptance. You're called to reflect the family character through love, forgiveness, and integrity, while finding your primary worth in this relationship rather than worldly achievements.
